captions.text:
This is a female Cimex lectularius. In the
quiet of night, she crawls from her hiding

place toward the carbon dioxide gas and warmth
emanating from your body. When she reaches

a patch of exposed flesh, she uses her small,
sharp beak to pierce your skin and slurp up

six times her weight in blood, leaving behind
an itchy welt. After returning home to the

underside of your mattress, a series of up
to seven males violently mate with her.

If this sounds like a bad dream, count yourself
lucky--for tens of thousands of people worldwide,

it's a nightly reality. These tiny parasites,
better known as bedbugs, have spread through

Los Angeles, New York and London over the
past 20 years, infesting the homes and hotels

of rich and poor alike. They've crept into
the cushions of movie theater seats and executive

offices, and hitched rides in library books
and subway cars. In the world of pests, bedbugs
may be the greatest invaders in all of history.

Or, more specifically, the greatest re-invaders.
Because bedbugs have actually been harassing

humans since the stone age. The problem worsened
when we crowded into towns and cities, and

became terrible when we invented central heating,
which helped bedbugs thrive year-round virtually
everywhere.

Until WWII, that is, when humans discovered
a class of synthetic insecticides that were

ultimately strong enough to drive bedbugs
from the US and Europe for half a century.

However, not only are many of those chemicals
now banned, but hardy bedbug individuals also

survived and multiplied, meaning that now,
bedbug populations are resistant to many of

our weapons against them. Meanwhile, increased
global travel has made pretty much any bed

in the world just a short flight away, both
for human jetsetters and their bedbug stowaways.

The one-two punch of insecticide resistance
and global transport has allowed bedbugs go

from nightmare to modern reality - the ultimate
comeback kid of the pest world.

Except that in a way, we've brought them back,
and this time around, they won't go down so

easily. So sleep tight, and don't let the
bedbugs b-- actually, we're kinda screwed.

comments.text:
Seriously.  They are ubiquitous and resilient.  Most pest control companies 
will not guarantee removal of bed bugs, because no matter how thorough you 
think you are, they can, and often will, survive and return with a 
vengeance.﻿
comments.author: Jesse Wallis

comments.text:
Solution:
1) make friends with the bed bugs
2) die
3) be a homeless dick and sleep outside
4) mate with them﻿

comments.text: Correct order: 3), 1), 4), 2)
comments.author: Stuart Hull

comments.text:
There are solutions.  They mostly involve hiring pest control 
professionals, since bed bugs tend to be widespread in a building by the 
time you notice them.  Don't keep it to yourself, tell your landlord or 
hire a pro if you are a house owner.  It's not shameful to have bedbugs- 
it's simply a problem that needs to be dealt with.  Here is Penn State 
Extension's take- http://ento.psu.edu/extension/factsheets/pdf/bedBugs.pdf. 
 Penn State's disclaimers are at the end of the article.﻿

comments.author: Raziel Qwazar

comments.text:
I have been watching the playlist of all the videos on this channel and 
while informative in a fun way about many things having to do with the 
earth in general, the channel nearly always chooses stories that illustrate 
how humans have fucked up and are ruining the good things and making the 
bad things stronger or better.  We know! We suck! People acting in our 
immediate best interests have made and will continue to make mistakes.   I 
don't disagree in general with the facts presented but a more apt channel 
name would be Minute-environmentalist.  I started watching these videos for 
the curiosity of natural knowledge  "The biggest organism on earth"  "Why 
is all the sand the same".  The channel is free to appeal to who they want 
and is clearly less preachy than many other purely environmental 
channels.  My opinion is to hope they would use their 
interesting presentation style and illustrate subjects from a purely 
natural education standpoint with very minor "human impact" pieces, similar 
to the BBC series, Planet Earth.﻿
comments.author: Ezra Po

comments.text: But it seems the natural world is stuck with human impact.

comments.text:
Buddy, until you've been bit by a bed bug, you don't know what true itchy 
torment is. I scraped the skin off my ankle because it was so itchy. All 11 
bites on my body turned into painful red welts which made me look diseased.
Being an overall healthy-looking guy, it was pretty embarrassing. The worst 
thing is, it has very little to do with hygiene. But most people will 
assume it's your fault.

psychological to those who have experienced them, and how easy they can 
spread. Talked about a couple who tried to seal up their belongings and 
throw them out in bags marked "bed bugs" only to watch people take their 
infested couches and rugs right before their eyes and despite the couple's 
warnings. Makes me paranoid about both traveling and garage sales.﻿

comments.author: Mantvydas Lisauskas

comments.text:
They live in carpets, too, bro. And if you try to go on an extended 
vacation to starve them out, they can also survive on shed skin cells for 
months. Apparently, smearing everything including yourself with vaseline is 
the only temporary solution, as they can't navigate through the sticky goo 
(and you still have to scrape all the trapped insects off your body every 
morning), and the only permanent solution is to heat treat and/or replace 
everything you own and move to a new house.

comments.text:
The good news is that bed bugs don't typically transmit harmful diseases. 
Their primary food source is humans, not animals. Also, unlike mosquitoes, 
they aren't typically going to move from household to household. That 
doesn't necessarily make them friendly, but they do rank pretty low on the 
danger scale. (I used to work for Orkin)﻿
